awd_titl_txt: Moving from correlation to mechanism: testing the role of temperature and oxygen change in the Great Ordovician Biodiversification Event
awd_abstract_narration:
Oxygen levels and temperature change are generally recognized as two of the most important environmental factors affecting marine ecosystems, both in the geologic past and in the modern ocean. This project examines the Great Ordovician Biodiversification Event (GOBE), a major increase in the diversity of marine life that occurred approximately 460 million years ago, when there were dramatic changes in oxygen levels and temperature. This project will use a unique combination of geological fieldwork, laboratory measurements of trace metal isotopes, Earth system modeling, and physiological insights from living organisms to understand the role that both oxygen and temperature play in driving major events in the history of life, such as evolutionary radiations and mass extinctions. The results also will help stakeholders better predict how modern global change will affect living marine populations, with implications for the future development of economic and food resources (e.g., fishing and aquaculture).   

This project will use an ecophysiological approach to test the causal role of oxygen and temperature change in driving biodiversity dynamics during the Great Ordovician Biodiversification Event. This integrated project will 1) build a record of Ordovician oceanic redox change using new Mo and U trace metal isotope measurements, and compile temperature estimates from the literature, 2) conduct the necessary physiological measurements on brachiopods, bryozoans, mollusks, and echinoderms that are required to fully leverage the Metabolic Index in addressing paleontological questions, 3) use Earth system models to build a time series of model states consistent with available geochemical data, and 4) use the Metabolic Index to evaluate the proportion of biotic change observed in the fossil record during the GOBE that can be explained by oxygen, temperature, and their synergistic combination. The use of physiological measurements to understand how ecosystem reorganizations can be mediated at the organismal scale creates mechanistic links that complement the descriptive and correlative methods for testing hypotheses of climate-ecosystem linkages. Broader Impacts of this proposal include early career training, ecological conservation, and a STEM outreach project with local high school robotics teams.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Oxygen levels and temperature change are generally recognized as two of the most important environmental factors affecting marine ecosystems. These factors often change in tandem during the environmental perturbations associated with evolutionary radiations and mass extinctions. Consequently, it is known that changes in oxygen and temperature correlate with major evolutionary changes in the fossil record, but researchers are unable to precisely track the causal role of each parameter. In this grant, we studied how oxygen and temperature changes affected animal life during the Great Ordovician Biodiversification Event (GOBE), one of the most dramatic evolutionary radiations in the history of animal life. Both factors have been hypothesized as drivers of this event, and our goal was to untangle the relative role.

To study how oxygen levels changed through the GOBE, we conducted both a detailed regional study and a database study. Specifically, we analyzed shale samples from the Road River Group of Yukon and reported a nearly continuous record of seafloor redox change from the upper Cambrian to Middle Devonian (Sperling et al., 2021). Bottom waters were largely anoxic (lacking oxygen) in the Richardson trough during the entirety of Road River Group deposition, with no visible changes in oxygen through the main pulses of the Ordovician radiation. In our second study (Stockey et al., in review), we present statistical learning analyses of a large dataset of geochemical data and associated geological context from the Neoproterozoic and Paleozoic sedimentary record, and then use Earth system modeling to link trends in redox-sensitive trace metal and organic carbon concentrations to the oxygenation of Earth’s oceans and atmosphere. Again, we found little change in oxygen levels through the Ordovician radiation. Together, these results suggest that global cooling may be a more likely evolutionary driver of the GOBE.

To investigate how oxygen requirements change with temperature in marine invertebrates, we made ecophysiological measurements (specifically measuring the critical oxygen level, or Pcrit, using direct respirometry) on 12 new species. This included the first measurements of this type for brittle stars, brachiopods, and crinoids. During the course of this grant, it became clear that oxygen requirements at low temperatures are commonly higher than expected. This posed an unexpected challenge in using the Metabolic Index framework to understand the role of cooling on global diversity. Thus, we developed two strategies for incorporating ‘bowl shaped’ Pcrit curves into the Metabolic Index framework. First, we developed a new formulation of the Metabolic Index, an Absolute Metabolic Index, that can delimit both the warm and cold edges of a species range (Duncan et al., 2023). Second, we generated a first-principles model for why thermal optima arise in Pcrit curves (Endress et al., In press). Finally, we completed a coupled ensemble Earth system and ecophysiological modeling study to evaluate the feasibility of surface oxygenation as a first-order control on extinction rates through the Phanerozoic (Stockey et al., 2021).

Overall, this grant supported 14 published, submitted, or in-press publications related to oxygen, temperature, and animal evolution during the early Paleozoic including papers in PNAS, Science Advances, Nature Communications, Current Biology, and PLoS Biology.

The project has involved interdisciplinary training for 11 early-career trainees at Stanford, including six graduate students, three undergraduate students, one post-doctoral scholar, and two research assistants. The grant has allowed these early career trainees to conduct field work, laboratory work, computational analyses, outreach and teaching to high school students, and present at multiple conferences. Trainees have led six first-author publications and are involved as co-authors on many more. This project provided further opportunities for training at our primary biological field station, the Friday Harbor Laboratories on San Juan Island, Washington State. The predominant native mussel in the Puget Sound region is the blue mussel Mytilus trossulus, which is threatened by the invasive mussel Mytilus galloprovincialis. Little is known about the spread of the non-native mussel and its impact on the local marine ecosystem (and particularly whether this may be related to global warming). A Stanford graduate student served as a teaching assistant for the invasive mussel outreach project at Friday Harbor Labs. During this 9-day lab, local high school students took an active role in gathering data on the incidence of these mussels and their hybrids via their DNA fingerprints. Students in the course learned how to utilize micropipettes and electrophoresis chambers, make PCR cycler solutions, prepare agarose gels, and analyze stained DNA gels. Their amassed data was included in a Puget Sound-wide study of invasive mussels. PI Sperling then delivered a Zoom lecture to the students, discussing the role of oxygen and temperature change in controlling animal life across Earth history, as well as his career path and how to prepare for science opportunities in college. This grant provided funding for both laboratory materials and participation by the Stanford graduate student.
